repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Third, Fourth and Fifth
            Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third,Fourth and Fifth
            Poverty Reduction Support Credit  ( PRSC) Project for
            Mozambique  were as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcomes was
            significant, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory,  Some
            lessons learned included: carefully chosen objectives and
            prior actions for policy development operations can provide
            the basis for the necessary conditions for better
            macroeconomic policy, good governance, and sound economic
            development. policy development operations can reduce
            poverty by increasing growth and improving institutions that
            have responsibilities for poverty reduction, but that focus
            was not sufficient for significant poverty reduction in
            Mozambique.development policy operations that use general
            budget support as the instrument for providing assistance
            can also be appropriate vehicles for the harmonization of
            donor strategic assistance. the political economy context
            can have critical impacts on the achievement of policy reform.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Third, Fourth, and Fifth
            Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third, Fourth, and Fifth
            Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project for Mozambique were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: importance of
            Government ownership, taking the time to nurture it, through
            dialogue an analysis of the political economy of reforms;
            working together with the rest of the donor community
            through the Group of nineteen donors (G19) is helpful,
            notwithstanding the difficulties and tensions resulting
            there from; the Performance Assessment Framework (PAF), as
            currently used, is too rigid to permit rapid and flexible
            response to emerging issues; the political economy of
            sensitive reforms needs to be well understood; and
            coordinated capacity building is essential.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Fifth Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit (PRSC-5) is the third in a second PRSC series
            designed to assist the Government of Mozambique (GoM) to
            implement key policy actions outlined in its 2005-2009
            second action plan for the reduction of absolute poverty
            (known as PARPA II by its Portuguese acronym) and in the
            performance assessment framework agreed by the government
            and the 19 external partners that provide General Budget
            Support (GBS) to GoM. In 2008 the government announced that
            it will extend the PARPA II by one year to include 2010,
            thereby strengthening sustainability and continuity with the
            next strategic document. PARPA II is mainly focused on
            shared growth and on the need for decentralization. Within
            this context, PRSC-5 is expected to help the GoM in (a) the
            consolidation and deepening of the institutional reforms in
            the area of macroeconomic management; (b) reforms in
            governance by supporting decentralization to enhance public
            investments and service delivery at the provincial and
            district level, and by supporting public sector reform; and
            (c) economic development by removing constraints to growth,
            such as infrastructure, and promoting agricultural growth.
            The PRSC-5 also supports the implementation of the
            government policy response to the higher global food and
            fuel prices. The operation will help the government to
            maintain macroeconomic stability while it continues to
            pursue a reform agenda that cannot be fully financed from
            domestic sources. The reforms should enable Mozambique to
            make further progress in reducing absolute poverty,
            improving the delivery of services and achieving the
            Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The alignment with the
            general budget support programs of 18 other donors and a
            joint focus on the priorities set out by the government in
            its comprehensive poverty reduction strategy, and on a
            common set of indicators to measure progress, should help
            improve the resource flow and improve aid effectiveness,
            thereby enhancing the chances of progress towards the MDGs.
